(This review is spoilerless.) 
Asobi Asobase is a very interesting serie for me in Summer 2018 but at the same time, can be one of the most obnoxious comedy serie around 2-3 years too. I know that comedy is very subjective and different people have different tastes. As you know, there are large amount of comedy anime in the market nowadays and what I am going to show you is how Asobi Asobase in short running viewing experiences, is very amazing in its own way of social humorous and references creativity and adaptation but at the same time, in long running viewing experiences, Asobi Asobasecan be a very boring and irritating serie as its presentation only rely on the same style of overreaction and exaggeration of both plots and characters. First, let me show you the good things that happen in Asobi Asobase which make me want to recommend this serie for you to watch.


I like the designs, relations and dynamic developments and progressions of the main cast which are Olivia, Hanako and Kasumi so much. Actually, I can proudly to say that I only watch this serie in some episode only to watch these three doing something ridiculous and idiotic like normal friends do. (In some serie, friendship buildings and executions are very weirdly beautiful and feeling so forced. They always say nice things to each others and never think in the bad way. They trust each other so much that they can even be lovers which want me cringe sometime.) 


These three show us how dynamical and along side the serie they have some progressions and developments since the very start. Olivia is a girl who want to be recognize by her very nature of normal girl, not a foreigner people which everyone always feel uncomfortable. Hanako is a kind of wanna be girl who like to have friend but cannot doing that as she is too bland, idiotic and innocent that other girls don't accept these nature of her except Olivia and Hanako. Kasumi is an awkward girl who can't be herself when facing others people but when she is with Olivia and Hanako, she can be herself who like to do something stupid and relaxing most of the time. Everyone have their own role and attribute as Olivia is a straight man who seem like the most normal while the other two Hanako is a main ridiculous and joke character and Kasumi support these ridiculousness and jokes from Hanako afterword.


These might be shallow perspective of why this serie is interesting and good to watch. Now let's discuss the main key point that make Asobi Asobase both good and bad at the same time.


For its presentation, Asobi Asobase still has to beware one important thing about the style of using “over-action” and “visualization changing” jokes repeatedly along out the entire serie which can be one of the most boring and unfunny thing for some viewers even though those style of presentations changed and developed with more creativity and uniqueness over the time. This serie can be pretty easy to predict on how the jokes and plots will be executed and even nearly guessed the ending resolutions in the next scenes most of the time if viewers who seen or notice the same style of presentations from the other series before hands. Also these jokes and style of scene executions were overused a lot that even the viewer who love to continue to watch the serie can get a bit boring and feeling cheesy too. A lot of viewers decide to drop this serie so fast after seeing these kind of repeated presentations.


After the circumstances of the previous problems that can be happen for some viewers, this serie begins to use a lot of references in their stories and even play jokes more often after the middle part. (but I guess they have started these style of references using since the first part which kind of hard to notice as some references are so old or don’t have any linked or stories to begin with that make it kind of charming for the second watch) This circumstances of serie begin to imply the tactic of using references as main factor as they use them a lot and even have an important role for viewer to understand the joke can be very dangerous as for some viewers. They can not get any laugh from the serie or even feeling funny if they don’t get or understand the references at all.


Even though, the ideas of telling story based on the randomness in girls’ school life are very new and creative in the field that most viewers have never seen before. (because all the school life comedy anime in the community right now are all the man-based viewing not in the girl-based much) But at the same time, they are like the double-edged sword where they can make viewers rather confused so easily about what currently happened in each scenes and plots. Also they make scenes and jokes from the previous to the next scenes that should have some continuity loss their tones and stories that can potentially make the story more engaging and interesting in the long running as viewers have something to get invested in.


Personally, the randomness will not bug me so much if the serie has some kind of good direction which now let's talk the thing that make me feel uncomfortable the most during the viewing experiences of Asobi Asobase, Pacing.


To be completely honest, even though fast pace direction of this serie can (kind of) build up a very well comedic atmosphere and ridicule nature of the serie as every scenes, tones and dialogues feel enthusiastic and look natural from the surface, but it can also be utterly annoying and irritating as hell. Most of the time, if not because of the built up based original stories, plots and dialogues, everything look so extremely force and corny as they look so out of place sometime. The direction of Asobi Asobase cut, swap or even make some built up tones of each scenes loose their momentum. There are too many things cramped in the same scenes which keep changing their attributes all the time. Making it even worse for the viewer to even try to figure out what is actual happened. It will hurt your brain so much and will make you feel a lot of confusion sometime.


And that is all my opinion about Asobi Asobase. This is a good serie for the time killing. Even though I point too many bad things in this review but Asobi Asobase still be a very charming serie to watch for more understanding in second and third times. You should give this serie a try. It might not be as bad as I say.


The final score is 7/10.

By far one of the funnies anime I have seen.
I always search for new comedy animes, I have seen Nichijou,Danshi Koukousei, Sakamoto desu ka,Arakawa Under the bridge, Minami Ke, and lots of  slice of life anime and Asobi Asobase is the funniest of them all, I guarantee you get a smile or big laugh every minute of this show.
Because of this anime I also had started to like the way they drew the eyelashes  of the three characters where I have first seen on Flemmy Speedraw(rokka no yuusha).
Despite the flaws of the three girls, i have fallen inlove with their personalities .

Nichijou if all the main characters were horrible people.
My anime of the season, maybe the year. This absurd comedy throws everything at you and none of it makes sense. For every normal Slice of life, shoujo manga trope they throw a curve ball, or maybe just eat the ball. The characters break out of their moe molds every few minutes and it's Hanako who takes the cake for me. Her absurd over-reactions and nonsense jumps to conclusion make this the most hilarious comedy anime in a long time.
Hurricane laugh scale: Category 5 non stop gags and wtf moments are guaranteed to destroy your sides andbring floods of tears. Catastrophic damage to your image of cute high school girls.

This show is definitely on crack, but it's good crack. Grade A crack. And I find it hilarious.
There isn't much to describe in way of plot. Plot=shenigans. But the girls' personalities are distinct and they bounce off one another really well. Everyone has their own little quirks that contribute to making the comedy consistent and make sure those gut-wrenching laughs keep coming.
Honestly, the first episode is a great indicator of what to expect. Watch it, and if it isn't your thing, rest assure that the show isn't for you. However, if it had you grinning like a madman, just know you're in for a treat.

"Sorekara do Shitano"
Good in-your-face humor, hilarious facial expressions, and impressive voice actors. Asobi Asobase is that one underdog comedy gem that will eventually get popular to the point where it'll reach god status. Or, I hope at least. 
The anime is basically a bunch of stories jumbled together with its juxtaposing palette colors that glitters cutesy and moe. A slapstick comedy that attempts to make you laugh from the outrageous actions of Middle School girls. Not everyone will appreciate its humor, not everyone will like this type of show. However, with what it's trying to offer to fans of comedy, I can confidently say thatit exceeds my expectations. The characters are lovable and amusing, with their interactions being even more so. There are a lot of memorable moments that will definitely appear in "Top 10 Funny Anime Moments" videos on YouTube. The animated faces of Hanako are ridiculous and hilarious. She's definitely in the spotlight, but that's not to say everyone else is subpar. The other two main characters are equally lovable and funny.


The theme songs are addicting. The Opening is a huge lie but still a calming listen. The Ending is very Rock and Metal, and it's awesome. 


The animation provides a contrasting effect, yet still manages to compliment the scenarios and gags. 


Asobi Asobase is a lovely gem. It deserves way more love. Much of its greatness stems from its comedic theme, and it perfects it well. It's not complex nor is it deep. It doesn't try so hard. It stays within its realm. It's basically a good, fun 12 episode series. That's enough for me.

This is an example of don't judge an anime by its cover. The light colours and relaxed depiction of the poster is just not like the anime at all. 
It is a crazy constantly emotion and drama fueled slice of life comedy with the most expressive characters I  have seen yet. 3 Girls having their typical club where they are to just be doing past time games, just ends with many random scenarios 
The animation is brilliant and shines when it comes to the characters personalities. The darker the emotions the better the animation. This show will have you laughing and is definitely wortha watch if you're into random humour

Now that I think about it, I don't always watch anime that fall under the slice of life/comedy genre. After seeing a few positive reviews of this anime, I decided to take a weekend to binge  watch it.
One of my favorite comedies is Sayanora Zetsubou Sensei, which has a bizarre, surreal, dark, sense of humor. If you're looking for something a little different, something lighthearted, yet surreal, I'd say this is worth a watch.

"For people who have watched Azumanga Daioh and Ichigo Mashimaro"


Ichigo Mashimaro - AA does the same "looks foreigner but ain't foreigner, doesn't know English but is forced to teach English" elaborated skit. It is so well-known to IM fans that I was surprised that this was recycled so blatantly. This issue with Olivia was stretched until it was not funny or even mention-worthy to squeeze out a laugh.


Azumanga Daioh -  Kurosawa-Sensei who was a charming but occasionally insecure one about marriage and life has a sister (whose design almost makes you go "kawaii-so!") here in AA. The pervy Kimura sensei has a even weirder brother here in AA. Such a joy to watch this series. Wish there were more episodes. The voice acting is incredible: personal favorite is side characcter Fujiwara-san, the Heian-styed classmate, voiced by Uchida Shuu. It's been a while since I've laughed this hard from anything. 
I loved how the series showed middle school girls with all their cuteness, pettiness, anger, humor, and friendship. The series did not shy away from making fun of itself, the high school girl anime tropes, and the creepiness that older men exhibit towards school age girls.
The series is very much episodic, each snippet fairly self contained, however they do do some callbacks (the enigmaticAozara, the Occult club, Maeda's butt cannon, etc...) that are hilarious. If I have any critique, it would be to have 1) more story arcs that last longer than one episode, 2) a last episode with some sort of closure.\n\n
However, the series as is is still incredibly hilarious and actually touches on a number of tropes in Japanese anime and critiques aspects of Japanese culture (kabedons, sex dolls, blonde people being perfect at English, etc...). 9 out of 10.

I haven't been watching new anime much in the recent years as most of the shows I see are soul-crushingly bad corporate garbage with no sense of authorship or purpose. Luckily, I stumbled haphazardly upon Asobi Asobase when it was recommended to me by YouTube algorithms, probably because of the precipitous amounts of unsubbed Nichijou clips I was watching immediately prior to improve my Japanese. And that's the first comparison I'm going to make to start out this interview (that is, between Asobi Asobase and Nichijou). For me, it's a flattering comparison, as Nichijou is practically unparalleled among school comedy slice-of-life anime – technically near-perfect,with brilliant characters that manage to be both subtle and over-the-top. That's a show that moves quickly between polar opposites, ultimately delivering strikingly funny comedy alongside a deep undercurrent of struggle for identity and joie-de-vivre. It fully deserves its status as a classic.


Asobi Asobase shares an anarchic, sharp and frequently jaded sense of humor with Nichijou. Its humor is entirely self-conscious; like the best comedies, it knows when to simply revel in immaturity and when to suddenly push the humor to a higher level of meta-comedic understanding. Asobi Asobase is funny, often very funny, and for that it deserves serious praise. Unfortunately, when compared to the heights reached by Nichijou, it falls a bit short. My list of issues with Asobi Asobase is short, but it's enough to push me significantly out of the show's universe; it doesn't immerse me as an environment, and it doesn't enthrall me as a media artifact. So here are some of my gripes.


First of all, the sound. The show itself is sound directed pretty decently, with well-placed sound effects, voice acting that ranges from pretty good to godly, and a generally self-consistent palette of sounds that give the show a distinct character (especially notable: that trumpet squeal that accompanies moments of shock and/or a quick change in atmosphere). Unfortunately, I am much, much less enthusiastic about the music and the music direction. The music itself only serves as a prop, lending the show a temporary nature of the “technical explanation” mood or zaniness or whatever. The director, Seiji Kishi (I'll get back to him, I guess) relies on that joke where music is suddenly yanked away during an abrupt mood shift far, far too heavily, to the point where it can be predicted from a mile away, and it reduces the value of the music itself as well.


Then, there's the OP and the ED. Okay, I have complicated feelings regarding the OP. Musically, the opening, where the rhythm slowly grinds from a slightly-too-slow tempo at the beginning to a reasonable clip, is fantastic – I mean, not awe-inspiring, but the way it brings the soundtrack to life slowly is certainly nice for an intro. Then, the words start. Have you looked up the lyrics to this? I would, if I were you. This falls under the category of theme songs that are directly about the show itself, rather than those that are only loosely related or borrowed from somewhere else. The speakers are the characters themselves, and the lyrics... Is this familiar to you? To me, the “classic trio” was a particularly characterized social unit, especially throughout high school, so I recognize some of what the theme song talks about. I'm not sure if it doesn't try a bit too hard to introduce some deeper dimension of nostalgia to the show, though. Asobi Asobase works hard to build a very convincing interpersonal dynamic between its principal characters through humor; the theme song, by comparison, comes off as a blunt attempt to invoke some nostalgia for our own innocent friendships of days past. Simply put, the characters that speak in the theme song don't seem like the characters that speak in the show. As intentional as this might be, the theme song seems forced, like a push a bit too hard from the director. This is one directorial choice that I question, but it doesn't reflect at all on the author of the manga, Rin Suzukawa. The ED, on the other hand, is pretty good, a lot better than the OP, and doesn't try to do that much or overstay its welcome.


About Suzukawa's writing, it's, simply put, pretty damn good, a lot of the time. For the most part, this is expertly-crafted comedy with few pretensions of any kind. The characters are funny, yet retain distinctive, but not gimmicky, personalities. Sure, they act ridiculously, and sometimes outside the bounds of realism, but their tendencies are all recognizably human, even recognizably ordinary. The show doesn't exactly reach any higher planes of existence like Nichijou, which just surpasses it in mechanical quality and far surpasses it in self-awareness, or a very different show like Niea Under 7, which does a much better and more convincing job of probing the nature of human relationships, albeit with lower quality in the comedic department. Instead, though, it comes with a very crisp and refreshing aftertaste of unpretentiousness.


However, there are certainly weaker bits, and they often undermine the stronger bits in a sort of disappointing way. By episode 12, the show kind of just tapers off into a circular pattern of making similarly-styled jokes. I understand the theoretical point of the lack of evolution across the length of Asobi Asobase (season 2, perhaps?) but I would more appreciate a show that allows itself to change and evolve. There are no “storylines” in Asobi Asobase; past events are referenced, but very little energy is carried from bit to bit, even sometimes within episodes. There are plenty of things I would've liked to have seen continued – the film for the culture festival, or whatever ended up happening between Aozora and Kasumi – and the lack of continuity ultimately builds to what ends up seeming like a lack of maturity. Again, to point to other examples, Nichijou had a subtle but ever-present overarching narrative that builds up to the meeting between Yuuko's and the professor's little social groups; Azumanga Daioh cyclically traversed the pace of life up to graduation, with graduation proving an ultimate end. In comparison, Asobi Asobase occupies a narrative wilderness, where nothing really builds into anything else.


Another bit of the aftertaste that is refreshing, and this is where I veer a bit into controversial territory: there is something a bit odd about idealizing the lives of schoolkids, especially young girls, that often comes off (whether intended or not) as fetishistic. The presence of the school environment is often integral to the nostalgia of school slice-of-life media, and the alienness of female social groups allows a male viewer (not that these are the only viewers, though! but feel free to read up on the male gaze; many of these shows are primarily male-created, after all) to maintain his distance from the material depicted. As with the better comedy slice-of-life shows, there is nothing fetishistic about the characters in Asobi Asobase; as I said previous, they are all ridiculous and heavily-flawed, but recognizably human. Perhaps they align at least slightly with stereotypes, but they aren't in any way defined by them. This is something that is also true of Nichijou, and one of the reasons that show is so great; it is something that is not so true of something like Azumanga Daioh. To round out the gender discussion, Asobi Asobase also contains a character who, it is implied, is trans; her depiction is sympathetic, but not at all patronizing. Olivia's older brother at one point launches into a long-winded speech about film theory that recognizably hits many of the points the show itself does. In this speech, he describes the student's film as a pastiche of pop culture icons, sort of (but “in Benjaminian terms”). Is he talking about the show itself? Well, yes and no: I think the show deviates quite severely from many the established pop culture tropes (a true pastiche would be something more along the lines of Azumanga), but it is certainly aware of its status as a pop culture icon, and attempts to reconstruct the purpose of such – to entertain – without falling into many of the pitfalls modern comedies fall into with regard to making meaning.


Still, Asobi Asobase possesses some flaws, and they are flaws that void the show overall of much of its significance and importance. I wish I could like Asobi Asobase more. For most of the duration of the show, I did like it more. But at the end I was left disappointed – the show was still relying on all of its gags and funny things, and I was conscious of the fact that it was about to end, and the show seemed not to care. This is television; it is a thing people get attached to, and it should acknowledge that at least somehow. So despite its style, wit, humor, and understatedness, I can't get fully behind Asobi Asobase just yet. Hopefully there's a season 2, and hopefully if it continues, the show's staff will find a way to allow the show the expressiveness that the ensemble cast they've compiled are so able to give us.

Just like with Teasing Master Takagi-san, what you see is what you get with Asobi Asobase. A slice of life comedy following the school lives of the pass-timers club members, Hanako, Olivia, and Kasumi. These girls are hilarious. Each of the girls have a trait about them that plays off the others very well. Now, that isn't groundbreaking for comedy, almost all comedy do this, but it is done very well here with great timing and visual gags that are very creative, especially with how the animators manipulated character facial expressions. Voice acting was also impressive especially with Kino, Hina as Hanako. The comedy canbe to immature for my taste at times, but hey at lest Asobi Asobase doesn't bullshit you with a needless story, or melodrama. There isn't much else to say, like I said, what you see is what you get.

I really enjoyed this anime! It's a feel good anime that is easy to watch and very entertaining. There were points in the story where I laughed so hard I had to pause and rewind. In terms of watch time, I was able to watch the entire season over my short thanksgiving break. The art style is hilarious as it incorporates super cute bishoujo elements with horrible facial expressions, in typical Japanese anime fashion. And I loved how each character stays true to their "comedic trope". I adore this sort of random slapstick humor but if you want something with a cohesive storyline I wouldn'twatch this. But if you just need an anime you can watch on an off without having to do much mental work this is the Anime!

This is the worst thing in the history of everything ever. I've had to attend three funerals in the past month because of it. This series, first of all, is pretty much the most funniest series of summer 2018.
 It's pretty much a slice of life series,but the many face expressions just makes it completely hilarious for me. 
 Think of the series nichijou( if you had seen it) and make their reactions 100 times over reactive than they are now, and there you have it.
 The thing that i don't pretty much like about this series is that it mostly doesn't have any story, pretty much like an episodic show to be honest.
 I would recommend this if you want a quick laughter from this years summer seasonanime series.

Ahh yes... the essence of youth.. or should I say Raw Middle Schoolers....
"Workshop of Fun"
It's not exactly lying or far from that because it's actually the main point of the show. I sometimes wonder how I was really drawn to this series. Well.. I have seen some which are similar like Danshi Koukousei no Nichijou, K-On! and other similar stuff that focus on the School-Slice of Life-Comedy routines for each episode. At first it gives the impression of the Kyoto Animation's usual series that always have the style of using cute girls to draw the audiences' attention but it seems that Lerche did the oppositefor this series. Well.. no.. I do not mean that the characters were drawn ugly and hideous or anything weird. It's just that you'll be in for a surprise if you see for yourself. The comedy factor for this series is next level and I'm sure there was never an episode where I didn't burst out laughing. I applaud the next level and intense comedy that this series has. I mean the facial expressions and voice acting match up very well too. The way every episode is going is like it's always giving a reminder that this show is not for girls and it's not what it looks like. Each episode is cut into segments and if not like this, it would be considered short episodes instead. It gives the feel of Danshi Koukousei no Nichijou but this series was able to do what that show wasn't able to do. To be honest, this is one of the only anime series where I wasn't able to make plot predictions very accurately even though I swear I could've seen it coming from a mile away. It's just that it always gets me every time and I'll just laugh it off instead of cringe in the moment. The opening theme is soothing and calm as it seems that this show is relaxing. Hehehe.. However....

It was like "and everything changed... when the fire nation attacked.." 

The show really ruins your expectations and it feels that cliches were devoured and then regurgitated right at your face saying "that's not what we really mean!!" I really like the contrasts of this show on how it switches from cute to hilariously bizarre. The art style appears to be relaxing but I didn't really find it as such because the lighting was too bright for me and it felt like you're in the afterlife. It's like the mood is always to bring light thoughts even though you're about to burst out laughing. The characters were all unique and I'm sure I can't bring similarities and I cannot compare them to other characters in other shows with the genre of comedy. Rest assured that if you want a show with no actual plot and no conflicts in the personal lives of the characters, then this show is one of them. I enjoyed this series very much because I never found a dull moment in this show as each moment is always keeping an intense comedy scene ready for you. I sure do hope that doesn't count as a spoiler because I am generalizing it right now. Overall this is a series that is worth to watch because shows like this are just for pure entertainment and satisfaction only comes with the willingness of the viewer. You can't really force yourself to like something new. But you can always have a great laugh with just the short moments in life. It's always the reactions that changes what's coming up. 


Asobi Asobase: Workshop of Fun 


Let it be something to add to your watchlist!

Well since Asobi Asobase didn't really have a central plot and honestly it was just messing around, I was able to think much deeper while watching about what other factors and hidden symbolism were subtly shown throughout the series. One thing for sure is that While using the Feminist Approach of Criticism, I have realized that this show is feminist. Not just because most of the characters were girls and women, but the show degrades its point of view to men. The only male characters shown in the anime were described only with negative attributes like creepiness, perversion and just plain ol' weird. Though the girls in the series had also their share of negative attributes, it seemed as if the show was telling that no matter how bad or distinguishing a characteristic is, you shouldn't feel bad for it. The show also briefly asserts about being independent women who don't really need men but I think it's just a bit exaggerated. Well.. there were other feminist symbols scattered throughout the show but I really don't know how to explain them all. Besides, I don't even know if I'm just exaggerating a normal show and being delusional or I landed on truth. Well.. anyway.. that's just a theory.. AN ANIME THEORY!! Thanks for reading.

Just personal scratch.
Advised, possible spoilers.
Opinion & Informal
Art: 7/10 It was good and felt like it had its own style. Anatomy and proportions checked out. The weird faces were pretty funny and they added a lot to the atmosphere as well as to the comedy. It didn't seem like they were relied on too much which is also a plus. The art was clean and was detailed at times. Nothing to complain about but I didn't feel like there was anything to praise either. The art was just good in general but wasn't impressive for the most part. 
Animation: 6/10 Clean. No shortcuts that seemed outof place and everything seemed quite well done. The special effects and impact scenes were nice to look at. It wasn't over the top. The fast animation wasn't too much above average. Most of the movements were simple and didn't have much complexity so everything was pretty mellow. 


Characters: 7/10 The characters were well done. They were the highlight of this show. The trio of girls in the Past-timers Club really made the comedy work. No one individual of the trio was overbearing and didn't steal the show. The dynamics between the characters and the amount of impact they individually made was balanced and felt natural. The character development was interesting too. The backstories and relations were quirky and each of the characters had their own flavor. In other words, not one character felt too bland and they each had enough life to them to make the comedy work. 


Plot: 5/10 About average in terms of setup and premise. It's just a cute girls doing cute things show. The spice was the comedy and that spice is what sets this apart from other similar shows. I could see myself recommending this show if I were asked for a comedy recommendation. 


Development: 6/10 Like the plot, there wasn't anything really outstanding about the development. It was a comedy done by cute girls. There wasn't some crazy world-changing development or anything like that. It was just 12 episodes of comedy. I liked it.


Music: 7/10 The OP and ED were clever but not new. I liked the contrasting image both OP and ED create for this show to someone who may have no clue what this show's about. The bgm was fitting enough but wasn't too memorable. There wasn't any real sound design.


Conclusion: 6/10 Felt a bit weak and abrupt. It decided to conclude the show just as is, as-is the specific skit end. There wasn't a whole conclusion sequence. The conclusion was just like an abrupt end to a YouTube video. Somewhat fitting, somewhat weak. I don't have much to praise or complain about.


Overall: 7/10 This was good. I liked this enough to have this come to mind when recommending a comedy to someone so that's a win.

Absolutely beautiful and unique art design. 
If I was going to try and be pretentious about it, I'd say it was contrasting the cute pastel crayon-like likes with the crassness of the humor, but I don't actually think it's conceptualized as That Deep, it was just really nice to look at. But hell, it might be, who knows.
It's a gag comedy with little overarching story-line. A cute girls doing cute things comedy series that is a little more interestingly attractive than others of the same vein, and with a little crasser humor.
But the crass humor has a great restraint to it, never really crossing overto being too 'disgusting' too often, but still being unique and distinctive. Great expressions and character body language. Physical humor that isn't focused to 'character gets hit and falls down'.\n\n
I would value it most for the distinctive art style, but most people I've find it much more funnier than I do. So it has a lot to offer.

...
Alright, typically I start my reviews out with some quippy introduction to get us in the mood for the review of the featured show I'm writing about, but nothing I could come up with write could come close to help introduce what I'm about to describe here.
Story:
Asobi Asobase is the story of Pastimer's club, a trio of girls who become...acquaintances after one of the girls, Nomura Kasumi, asks the seemingly foreign Olivia on help with English despite Olivia not actually knowing a great deal of English herself.  This, with adding the last (and arguably strangest) of the girls, Hanako Honda, creates the basis of whatthe synopsis describes as a "Surreal School-life Comedy".  Words cannot fully describe what it means to watch this show, but I'll try my damndest.


As a school comedy, Asobi Asobase is a series heavily dedicated on doing whatever it can to get a laugh out of the audience, splitting each episode into an A and B part (usually separate stories) in order to vary up what the audience gets to see and contain each episode as a separate experience.  That's the boring stuff.  Here's where things go awry.


'Surreal' is pretty much the closest you can get for a word to describe this show.  Personally, I describe it as a 'mean-spirited Nichijou'.  A typical episode involves a story featuring the show's main trio doing a pastime or some other before going off the rails only a minute or two later, continuing down the hill until you're left in a state of shock and intrigue where the only thought running through your mind is "Where is this going?"  This is primarily due to the fact that Asobi Asobase is not a happy go lucky comedy where there're bright colors or comedic anger to make the situation cheerful, but instead, a comedy series that utilizes more dark, disturbing, bizarre, or awkward scenarios in order to convey its comedic forte.


That being said, the show isn't always even with its pacing.  The instances where the show seems normal for once feel like they drag on too long, and that kind of stuff happens more often than it seems.  Especially towards the latter episodes where everything has escalated to the point of making the early episodes look like child's play, the moments where the show drags on stick out like a sore thumb.


Asobi Asobase is NOT your typical school comedy, but instead a darker representative of that genre featuring more disturbing imagery, exaggeration in the other direction, manipulation, and the unexpected.  As a result, this oddity feature makes this a show not really suited for everyone, because lord knows every new episode presents me with something new to haunt my nightmares.


Overview:

+/- ...I don't know what to say really.


Characters:


The best way to describe our main trio is: Hanako, rich girl who not only has weird taste in fashion, but is also prone to bouts of heavy mood swings, Kasumi, the quiet androphobic fujoshi with a hidden sadistic streak, and Olivia, the not foreign foreigner who's typically the innocent one in most situations despite having a mean streak like her compatriots.  These three are typically the main focal point of each story/sub story, which even if they aren't, will find some way to jam themselves in and make a mess of everything, usually by virtue of the three of them bumbling about and maybe burn a place or two down in the process of doing so.  They're such a cohesive unit that I at times think they should've separated them for just a little more to let individual wackiness come about instead of always letting them converge together to create mayhem.  It doesn't happen enough, and that would've helped to round out their own character instead of condensing the weirdness.


On that note though, the side characters come into play as only adding to the various forms of strangeness that this series is capable of concocting.  Our candidates include a seemingly unthreatening student council with an intense glare, actual witches in the occult club, the androgynous...individual voiced by Aoi Yuuki of all people, the servant Maeda capable of shooting laser beams out of his ass (I wish I was kidding), sentient sex robots, and other various nutjobs that make only further solidify why it makes it difficult to review this show without questioning myself what on earth I was watching to begin with.


Overview:

+  ...Interesting cast


Art:


Produced by Lerche, the art is a peculiar beast that I put a lot of the blame on for making this show as weird as it is.  The art is done in this simple, yellowish pastel style that makes everything seem like a painting.  For the most part.  Due to the nature of this show however, the show half the time doesn't look like that, but instead distorts anything and anyone to appear like a satan spawn whenever Lerche damn well feels like it, ranging from cartoony exaggerated lips as the bare minimum of distortion, to realistic cartoon faces that look like the cheap halloween masks at your nearest department store.


This extends even further to the comedy, where the variance is so great you could make a color spectrum out of it, ranging from your typical sparkles to black and white frames with a singular menacing eye starting at you through the screen to get the point across.  The consistency in all this however comes from how the show hardly resembles any other school comedy by really driving home the darker presentation by focusing on being uncomfortable and sometimes difficult to watch instead of appealing to your senses.  Yet somehow it all works and I'm not sure how I sat through this cause there is a lot of genuine nightmare fuel here.


Overview:

+ Unique artstyle

+ Consistency?  (At scaring me, that's for sure.)


Sound:


So the comedy is weird, the characters are weirder, and the art makes both of those even more weird.  Surely the songs and voice acting are normal, right?  God I wish.  Our featured OP, "Suripisu" by the three seiyuus of the main trio is...a very fitting name for just everything.  It's a bright and cheerful seiyuu song that doesn't really sound out of the ordinary until you realize that it's something meant to lull you into a false sense of security before the show starts and shows you why the opening is called 'Surprise'.


Then there's the ED.  "Inkya Impulse", again sung by the show's main voice actors is a death metal piece that gave me genuine fear upon first hearing it.  It's one of those things that you don't expect until it actually happens, and really puts a lot of things into perspective when you compare how different the OP and ED are from each other.  Like...fuck, what the hell, Lerche?


On that note props to Hina Kino, as her performance as Hanako not only made the character an absolute terror to watch as she spazzed about the screen reaching unholy octaves that could only be reached by a worshipper of satan, but really helped sell on the surrealistic humor that was needed from the show to succeed.  So kudos to her.


Overview:

+ Very...expressive voice acting

+/- What are these songs...


Personal Enjoyment:


...Fuck.  What the hell am I supposed to say here?  Given how my introductory quips were drained dry before I even started, and my section overviews surmount to me asking the question of "What in the actual hell was all of that", my actual enjoyment of Asobi Asobase really just amounts to confusion, pleasure, frustration, discomfort, and confusion again all at the same time.  It's not as if I don't know what's going on, because if I didn't, I would have more to say in that regard.


Quite simply, Asobi Asobase is an experience that going in blind really put a lot of what I knew to be comedy into perspective.  Honestly my first thought at seeing it was "Oh, a Lerche comedy.  That seems like it could be good."  Then I end up with this and I have no idea what the fuck I just watched since my expectations were completely different to the casual presentation of death threats, blackmailing, and the breaking of about seventy two bones in a girl's body fighting over a clubroom.


As such, the only recommendation that I can really give is to watch the damned thing.  Seriously, go watch it.  It's one of those things that you have to 'see to believe', and forming your own opinion in this regard is important due to the ever present law of 'Comedy is Subjective', and the fact that this review is just 1400 words of me trying to make heads or tails of this show.

This is the first time I write a review, and this shows deserves it. I've watched hundreds of animes and this is going up to my top 3 right away.
One of the main reasons was the incredible job they did at hiding what this show really is. When I read the synopsis and started watching the opening I thought this would be just about cute girls, and then I knew I was completely WRONG. This is, actually, top tier absurd comedy!
Story: There's no story, it's just short bizarre situations that get worse and worse until they get completely out of hand.
Art: The art is oneof the best things about the show, because at first you see a kind of childish cute art style and then when things get weird the art is completely messed up, like the most exaggerated drawings you'll ever see in an anime. It's f*king amazing!


Sound: This is the best thing about this show. The 3 main actresses aren't very famous because they are kinda new, but they are the best seiyuus I've heard this year so far. You can feel the passion and the spirit they put into the show, specially Hina Kino (Hanako Honda) who I'd vote for seiyuu of the year no doubt. She makes such a good job at following with the craziness of the show and her shouts, shrieks and all other stuff is so passionate... But the best part of the anime's sound is the ending. I totally recommend you to hear the full ending in YouTube and hear to these 3 seiyuus making amazing metalcore shouts!


Characters: I'm now totally a fan of Hanako Honda. She has such personality... Innocent, then evil, then crazy... I haven't laughed as much as with her in a long time. Also Olivia's situation is very funny (won't spoil it) but she's actually the most normal girl, since Kasumi looks pretty shy but has many secrets... Also the side characters are very fun and absurd and it's really refreshing that none of them are really cliche characters.


Enjoyment: I have cried in all of the 12 episodes, but because I was laughing too much. There are quiet moments, of course, but in the end there's always something that makes you laugh and scream.


Overall: If you enjoy comedy, I can't recommend this enough. You'll love it, 100%. I give it a 11/10 and I hope that there are more seasons, or at least we can enjoy Hina Kino as a main character in the future too.

Let me first start by saying:
The plot isn’t exactly deep and the characters aren’t the most complex, but that’s not what I look for in a comedy. The comedic aspects are the most important in judging this genre and this show blows it out of the water. I can’t tell you how many times I’ve laughed my ass off watching this, which isn’t a easy feat considering how critical and cynical I’ve become watching anime over the years.
Plot: 5
The story is a surrealistic, slice of life comedy series centering around 3 high school girls where they hang out and play different activities, hence their clubnamed the Past-timers club. What’s most important in this show is our MC trio- Hanako, Oliva & Katsumi. It’s here where we see them in all these different,  surrealistic situations and see how they deal with it in a light hearted, comedic way. 


The comedy timing, goofy facial expressions and dialogue are amazing and well executed. It never feels like the show is repeating the same joke at times like Grand Blue (which is one of the few flaws I have with that series). 


Characters: 7

The characters are fun, likeable, diverse, have interesting little traits and gags that the writer plays on at times, but never gets boring. I love all three girls equally and the chemistry they have together. Some of side characters I like are the student president, Hanako’s butler and Olivia’s otaku brother.


Sounds: 9

The opening is amazing. The visuals and the lighthearted, fun soundtrack capture well what this series is supposed to be about. The osts are really great and I like the rock ending with the sketchy visuals too  


Animation: 7

The animation is good for the most part. I don’t really have anything else to say about it xD


Overall: 8

In terms of enjoyment, I would rate this as 10/10 comedy gold.

Asobi Asobase is one of those anime I would recommend to anyone who just wants to relax and have a good laugh. In terms of comedy alone, Asobi Asobase isn’t just the best comedy anime this season, but overall one of the best I’ve seen in anime.

If there was a comedy that made waves in the Summer of 2018, then Asobi Asobase did that in spades as to how it just didn't give a fuck...
Asobi Asobase might as first look like any cute girls doing cute things slice of life comedy but ohhh you are mistaken as that is what it only WANTS you to think. Asobi Asobase is more in line with black comedy and stretching it's limits to how crass, nonsensical and degrading it can make our trio of main characters Hanako Honda voiced by Hina Kino, Olivia voiced by Rika Nagae and Kasumi Nomura voiced by Konomi Kohara.
AsobiAsobase's main basis of comedy at first to lure you in with a situation, flip it on it's head to most absurd and surreal degree and mainly at the expense of our main trio in the process. Hanako is the hyper genki type who is actually the smartest out of the trio yet has a VERY hair triggered temper especially when involves being popular or her small boobs, Olivia (LA's favourite), is the non-foreigner foreigner type character, as in she was born in Japan and doesn't know a lick of English but looks foreign, this becomes a running gag that only spirals out of control in most skits, but in terms of personality, she's one of the less educated characters but more sane to counterbalance Hanako and she wasn't just LA's favourite character in the anime but for the Summer of 2018 because of this. Finally we have Kasumi who counterbalances both Hanako and Olivia's antics but she has some of her own craziness, she for the most part is middling in the sanity department, is also shy but can change in an instant when it involves games, has a fear of men yet likes to writing BL...as LA says "middling". Asobi Asobase's main draw is of how many of the comedy as crass and nonsensical it is, well since it involves our main trio, they have GREAT chemistry together and add with the insanely overexaggerated reaction shots, only makes Asobi Asobase's surreal comedy all the more interesting.


OK, now the elephant in the room, LA knows that some of the comedy can cross the line at times and it's a black comedy disguised as a cute girls doing cute things kind of anime but serious talk, if you laugh at the comedy because of the joke landed fine, but LA doesn't think the overreaction that people give about Asobi Asobase isn't exactly warranted, like you'd expect a black comedy like Asobi Asobase to be clean and pure because it's funny and crazy as fuck yet you won't acknowledge it for what it really is and it shows it's true colors from the first episode alone and because of that it can't cross the line?. Your asking a black comedy that crosses the line multiple times and doesn't give a crap what you think to be in the same bar and "ethical", it's like asking South Park to be morally sane.


Like, LA felt some of it's skits weren't comfortable as well but LA didn't dish out it being "the worst thing ever" because once again, most of the comedy's punchlines boomerangs to our main trio of crazy characters in the process and for making Asobi Asobase...what it is. Like there is Tsugumi Aozora voiced by Aoi Yuuki who we really don't know is a girl or boy that it's completely ambiguous all throughout the anime yet our main trio gets the short end of the stick every time...or they're just stupid. All LA is saying the "outrage" towards Asobi Asobase is unwarranted for one little thing, like you do realize anime comedies like Asobi Asobase wasn't the first to do this kind of thing, have you ever heard of Yondemasu yo, Azazel-san?.


Ok, sorry for going serious there, LA just had to let that all out. 


*ahem* so, the comedy, well the comedy works well due to the trio's bombastic chemistry with one another, coupled with the outrageous crazy reactions, just makes the comedy tenfolds better. The thing is due to our main trio being all over the place in terms of personalities it also just makes the comedy unpredictable ALL the way through, this is especially in the case of Hanako and her antics especially when it involves Hanako's butler. Olivia's foreign English scthick sticks but it also gets played around with to the point of it being an evolving running gag and finally Kasumi like Olivia has her comedic running gags from time to time but Kasumi also has tints of Hanako's batshit craziness in the mix as well. Due to how batshit crazy the characters gets, the comedy not only crosses the line but it's also unbelievably unpredictable as well as many of it's running gags not being run to the ground due to how it constantly evolves how much crazier it takes it's running gags to the point of absurdity, there is method to the madnass and Asobi Asobase quite easily found it. As for Asobi Asobase's more isolated skits, they for the most part don't affect skits further down (besides some that subverts this) and like Asobi Asobase, they veer into the unpredictable and batshit craziness with all the insanely detailed overreactions to boot, Asobi Asobase keeps it's personality intact and keeps up the craziness ALL. THE. WAY. THROUGH. Yes if there is anything to say about Asobi Asobase with everything being said, is that this was thee comedy anime of Summer 2018 that you just had to watch.


In terms of animation by Lerche, well with everything LA talked about with the surreal and bombastic reactions, yes the animation can go from moe slice of life, to surreal madness in a blink of an eye and especially great detail in the facial reactions makes this simple comedy anime quite unique on that front. Like LA can't exactly show you, you just need to watch it and see, ...it's just absurdity incarnate that is wrapped in a cutezy not-so cutezy slice of life anime...it's amazing. Lerche pretty much went all out and like Asobi Asobase's comedy, it delivered in spades all the way through.


Voice work, well what can LA say....HINA KINO'S MANDRAKE SCREAMING WAS GREAT, no but seriously Hina Kino was great as Hanako as she had some of the more overreacted reactions in the entire cast, along with Konomi Kohara as Kasumi with her various vocal ranges from shy to instantly stoic mannerism. Rika Nagae also did amazingly well, for doing the broken Japanese but also broken English was hilarious for LA but like Hina and Konomi, well Rika's overreactions and one-liners are priceless as well. If there was anyone LA had to give MVP then it would be Hina Kino all due her manaic'd mandrake screaming must had been killer on her throat (to think LA first knew her as the psycho Tiki from Symphogear AXZ, she's even more batshit psycho as Hanako here). Also from voice work, well LA just loved the ED, as most endings have the seiyuu's sing typical J-Pop to run this over with the ED, Asobi Asobase uses fucking death metal to contrast to the moe J-Pop of it's OP and it's glorious as the main trio's seiyuu's are singing in death metal and quite easily this ED gained LA's favourite ED of Summer 2018.


Also on the topic of ED's, Asobi Asobase has at times after credit segments...where the seiyuu's use HAND puppets and does a random skit pertaining to games taken to extreme degrees, it's for shits and giggles but LA loves those too...


Asobi Asobase is one wild ride and be it the unwarranted controversies to the comedy itself with it's crazy cast of characters and just it's nonsensical nature that just doesn't give a crap, well Asobi Asobase pretty much did it's job and made one hell of crazy, funny comedy anime in the process. Asobi Aosbase is quite obviously LA's favorite comedy of Summer 2018 and might be one of LA's favorite animes of Summer 2018 for having the guts to push the boundaries of comedy and no less under the guise of being a cute girls doing cute things genre!

Story: 10/10
There's not much to say here since it's a Slice of Life anime and it doesn't really have a proper story but it was still fun to watch.Basically, Asobi Asobase is about 3 crazy, hilarious, cute and insane middle school girls and what they get into in the "past timers' club", which they created. The other characters are all great as well.I'll talk about them later.


Art: 10/10

Asobi Asobase has its own unique art style, like Yuyushiki or Nichijou. At first I felt a bit turned off by it but after a bit I got used to it and came to appreciate it. I also love the many facial expressions that the characters make, they're fucking hilarious. The characters are all adorable but also scary at times. This is why I love Asobi Asobase's animation style. Animation other than the characters such as the classrooms, were nice too.

There's a saying that goes "don't judge a book by its cover". You shouldn't judge an anime by its cover, name or even opening song either.. There are many great ones such as 'Is the Order a Rabbit' and 'Comic Girls'. Anyway, the opening song is very nice and happy sounding, which is why it's very deceiving. After 5 minutes into the 1st episode you begin to realise that these characters are not adorable, cute and cuddly characters, but cute, insane, stupid and borderline terrifying characters. The characters are all fucking insane. Yeah they're cute and all but fuck they're insane. Like I said before, the opening song deceives you. The 3 main characters, Olivia, Kasumi and Hanako, are 3 teenage girls who arre in middle school. They're in the past timers club. This all seems nice and cute but as you go through each episode you're basically going deeper into Hell. A Hell that's very satisfying. The other characters are all mad too. Maeda is one of them. He shoots laser beams out of his ass. Yes, laser beams. He's the butler in Hanako's house and is there because he was anal probed by aliens. Yeah, this show is crazy. I could go on a tangent but you should watch the show for yourself. Asobi Asobase's characters are like that one drunk homeless guy you see on your way home from work everyday. Nice guy who will approach you and say random things, but clearly crazy. The characters are mostly nice, but they're severely mentally ill, probably.

I rate this anime 10/10 overall. I loved this anime and I think anyone who's into slice of life, comedy anime will enjoy it too. i really hope there's a second season. I recommend this anime to anyone who is into slice of life, comedy anime.

Asobi Asobase - A chaotic and exaggerated mess of an anime!
Pretty sure this review is completely spoiler-free and any detail I give about the characters is revealed during the first episode, but there can always be a spoiler I am not aware.
Sorekara do shitano…
Upon looking at Asobi Asobase for the first time, I thought it was the usual high school-themed CGDCT (Cute Girls Doing Cute Things) anime with some weird facial expression here and there but I could not be more wrong. I typically avoid this type of anime because they are not entertaining at all, as they all share a similar premise with thesame types of cute girls and that just bores me to death. For some reason, I decided to give this anime a try based on the preview but I still were not optimistic about it, however, it became my favorite anime of the season hands down and my second favorite anime mainly focused on comedy as of now. Enough with introductions and let us start the actual review.


I am going to start with a short description and comment on the story because there is not much to talk about it anyway. Asobi Asobase is the type of anime that does not have an elaborated story and every episode consists of a couple of uncomfortable and hilarious incidents between the three protagonists and the rest of the cast. Its simplicity works in this case and it even offers some continuity and the characters relationships are consistent. It gets very surreal and foolish and you might ask yourself why a drama tag? Is this actually a serious story in any way? In short: absolutely not. In my opinion, it has a Drama tag due to all the over-dramatic reactions of the girls that turn every little misunderstanding into a huge 'drama'. Hanako is a complete drama queen. At first, the story looks like a variant of Dagashi Kashi as it focuses on classic Japanese games instead of candy but it has quite a variety of content. Sometimes it is about their club, sometimes it is about a side character mystery, and sometimes it is about an innocent dialog about sex. You never expect what is going to happen next in this surreal and ridiculous school comedy.


Now we get to the part that I consider the most important about this show, its characters. The focus is obviously the main characters hideous and completely dysfunctional personalities. 

Firstly, I am going to focus on Hanako, my favorite character. Hanako initially looks innocent, cheerful and playful, though she is actually a character with a pretty distorted mind that usually causes the biggest incidents and awkward situations in order to attain popularity among her schoolmates. It is also worth noting that the voice actor really did a great job with this role as she managed to sound completely hysterical and exaggerated, thus fitting the character perfectly. Every Hanako exaggeration is ensured entertainment.

Secondly, we have Olivia, a character that looks like the typical cute foreign transfer student, except she is not really a foreign student and there is nothing cute about her manipulative personality. Olivia is a sadistic character that enjoys having fun mocking Hanako's ingenuity and delusions. She really is not the generic type of foreign transfer student you expect at first.

Lastly, there is the bookworm Kasumi. A serious and clear-minded quiet girl that reluctantly becomes friends with Olivia and Hanako or that is what it might seem at first. Just like the rest, you soon find out she can be just as chaotic as the other girls. She can be spiteful and sadistic at times. While she is typically the most “normal” character on this cast, she also has her deal of problems and that reflects on her character, which originates interesting scenarios and character interactions.

The rest of the cast just adds to the craziness of the main characters and the more you watch the more you learn that everyone is crazy in their own way. But what really shines is how dynamic the trio is.


When it comes to the artwork and sound there is not much to write. The music is not particularly memorable but it fits the type of show. The voice actors have to be praised though. They are one of the reasons this anime is so fun, their performance fits their characters like a glove. The artwork is decent and so are the characters design but the little details and exaggerated facial expressions make up for the seemingly generic school-themed art.


Finally, it is time to write about my personal enjoyment and conclusions. I would lie if I told the enjoyment does not heavily weight on my ratings, after all the main point of anime is to entertain, among other objectives. This is not an intriguing or thought-provoking anime, this is a straight-up comedy with a very unpredictable trio of protagonists. I find it great unlike the rest of CGDCT anime as it does not rely on its characters cuteness or lovable personalities, neither tries to sexualize them. Asobi Asobase does the opposite. All the three main girls have ugly personalities and are not lovable at the very least, however, that is why I like them so much. There are no “imouto”, “tsundere”, “yuri characters”, and so on. If you are like me and hate repetitive CGDCT and high school-themed comedies, you should try Asobi Asobase. It manages to create a fresh anime from many overused genres replete with clichés and copy-pasted characters and scenes. Despite all this, Asobi Asobase might be a very polarizing anime as you either love or hate it. You either love its characters and comedy or you might completely hate it, but that is all up to you and I just hope this review increased your curiosity about this anime that can be quiet deceiving based on its innocent appearance and opening. You just have to watch the first episode to decide. I instantly fell in love with it and loved every single moment of this show. I am really sad it is over and I hope an announcement for season 2 will be revealed soon.

The anime starts out with a very heartfelt opening song. You find yourself saying "Okay were we go another anime about cute girls doing cute things." And here I sit getting strapped in for a nice comfy ride. Then the episode starts and shit basically hits the fan. An intense game of rock paper scissors with an end result of one of our main characters getting her breasts slapped and the other one getting a set of fingers jammed up her nose. "What the hell am I even watching?! this is hilarious!" I found myself saying after the first 5 minutes of Asobi Asobase. Thestory is a simple one about girls just trying to have a fun time while in school. In the beginning they focus on a lot of past-timers games but as the anime goes along it just becomes an anime about these girls being involved in different situations.


Lerche did a really good job with the animation. It felt different from anime I usually watch. The art seemed 'sketchy" but in a good way, like the character designs were not smooth but I liked it. it was different.


The opening like I said was very upbeat and enjoyable. The ending is going to be up for ending of the YEAR. yes ending of the year, this is one of the best endings I have heard in an anime in quite sometime. The heavy metal went perfectly with how this anime was overall. Straight crazy.


The characters were seriously flawless. I mean they each had their flaws in the show but to me the viewer I found nothing wrong with any of them. they each had their own charm and I enjoyed them all


The anime was really enjoyable. I looked forward to it every week because it started my week off right with a huge smile on my face.


This is one of if not THE BEST ANIME OF THE SEASON for the Summer 2018 season. I cannot recommend this anime more to anyone just looking for comedy that will keep you laughing constantly throughout this series.

Asobi Asobase: An Unserious Review (minor spoilers)
I have a terrible weakness for comedy. It’s probably a genetic mutation, much like my meme addiction. Asobi Asobase ticks all the boxes for me. It takes absurdist comedy in one hand, a pair of scissors in the other, and proceeds to run around claiming innocence.
When watching that diabetes-inducing OP for the first time, one would be inclined to think this was a charming little light comedy for kids. This is, in fact, the first joke. The reality is not “cute girls doing cute things,” but rather “cute girls pouring bleach into your brain.” Asobi Asobase sets a tablewith all the genre trimmings, offers the viewer a menu of tropes, and then recruits them into the Axis Cult. Adult humour is acted out by children, the smartest character is bat-balls-barmy, and innocent games always result in mayhem. The old “bait-and-switch” style of humour can trip over its own momentum in some shows, but Asobi Asobase carries it off successfully for a whole season.


The lead characters of this adorable acid trip of a show are Hanako “Screaming Meme” Honda, Kasumi “Filth Senpai” Nomura, and Olivia, the Social Moth of America. The three form a club, make immediate enemies of the student council, get invaded by other clubs, and accidentally burn down buildings. Each episode is split up into three or four parts that act like individual comedy sketches. The result is something like Monty Python’s Flying Circus; there are occasional fourth wall breaks, nonsensical situations with arbitrary resolutions, and characters with all the common sense of a directionally challenged salmon. It’s a fast moving structure that suits the style of comedy well. While trying to process the last gag, the action will move on to another before you can say nani.


If there were one gripe I had with this show, it would be that the story doesn’t really go anywhere. Most of the sketches are non-linear; you could shuffle and rearrange them and nobody would notice. That said, there is a tiny thread of continuity connecting one episode to the next. It isn’t a traditional story in the sense of a beginning, middle and end. It has a beginning, lots of middle, and no end whatsoever. On one hand, this seems a little unsatisfying. On the other, it creates the illusion that these three lunatics will remain this way forever: playing games, making trouble, and turning their whole world into a massive meme.


There are many ways to put an intelligent piece of work together. A moving romance speaks to the heart. A compelling sci-fi speaks to the mind. Asobi Asobase is an adrenaline shot straight to the diaphragm. Enjoy the laughter spasms.
